abstract.text: Focus on a part of an image by applying Gaussian blur and gradient masks.

inlineContent.text: You can selectively blur areas of an image using
filter.

abstract.text: Applying a masked variable blur effect to selectively focus on a portion of the scene

inlineContent.text: You specify the region to blur by applying a mask image; the shape and values of the mask image determine the location and strength of the blurring. Creating this effect involves the following steps:
To focus on a strip across the image, create two linear gradients representing the portions of the image to blur.
To focus on a circular region in the image, create a radial gradient centered on the region to keep sharp.
Composite the gradients into a mask.
Apply Core Imageâ€™s
filter to the original image, inputting the created mask.

content.text: Focusing on a Strip of the Image

inlineContent.text: You can build your mask in any shape, but the general strategy remains the same: leave the mask transparent where you want the original image to stay sharp and focused. This section covers focusing on a horizontal strip.
To build a mask that leaves out a stripe, create linear gradients from a single color, such as green or gray. Our goal is to build the mask shown in Figure 2.
The linear gradients cause the blur to taper smoothly as it approaches the focused stripe of the image. The Core Image
named
generates filters of the desired color. The linear gradient has four parameters:
A
representing the starting position of the gradient.
A
representing the ending position of the gradient.
A
representing the first color to use in the gradient.
A
representing the sexond color to use in the gradient.
Compute the start and stop points of the gradient as fractions of the image height, as obtained through
. For this particular mask and example image, focus on the area near the middle, in the second quarter of the image. Set the linear gradientâ€™s
and
to reflect the region through which the gradient tapers.
The lower gradient should complement the upper gradient, so that their combined coverage delineates the entire area to blur. Express the starting
y-value at
of the image height and taper to
, where the top gradient began. This leaves a gap in the combined mask through which the sharp image will show.

content.text: Creating a Mask by Compositing Linear Gradients

inlineContent.text: To create a mask that dilineates where and how strong a blur to apply, combine the two linear gradients.

abstract.text: Add two mutually exclusive linear gradients to create a mask

inlineContent.text: Since the gradients themselves are
objects, compositing them is as simple as concatenating their filter outputs to a compositing filter.  Use the built-in
named
to composite two images additively.
The resulting mask is now ready to be applied as part of the
filter.
In order to focus on a circular region of an image, you can create a Core Image
filter.
The filter takes four parameters:
A CGPoint representing the center of the effect as x and y coordinates.
center
A
representing the first color to use in the gradient.
color0
A
representing the second color to use in the gradient.
color1
A
representing the radius of the starting circle to use in the gradient.
radius0
A
representing the radius of the ending circle to use in the gradient.
radius1

pointing to the center of the region you want to leave unblurred.

in this example. You can tweak this parameter to determine the size of the sharp region.

in this example. Tweaking this parameter changes the extent of the blurâ€™s tapering effect; a larger value makes the blur more gradual, whereas a smaller value makes the image transition more abruptly from sharp (at

As with the linear gradients, set

This yields a circular mask to use with the
filter.

content.text: Masking the Blurred Image to Apply Selective Focus

inlineContent.text: The final step is applying your choice of mask with the input image. The
built-in
accomplishes this task with the following input parameters:
Set to the original, unprocessed
A float representing the area of effect.
An image that masks an area on the input image with the type

The resulting image shows the original image with portions blurred out according to the mask applied. The linear gradient mask results in an output image focused on a strip, and the radial gradient mask results in an output image focused on a circular region.
